page.title: 05KILSPINDIE
page.content: This is the name given to the area of land which stretches from the western edge of the bay to the north of the village between the main road and the sea. It is said that the name derives from the cell of St Pansandus, a Celtic missionary. The scanty ruins of Kilspindie Castle lie in a field just below the parish churchyard. At Kilspindie Point itself is the former custom-house, Aberlady once being the port for Haddington. The house is now converted to domestic occupation. Next to it is the club-house of Kilspindie Golf Course. Golf is played over the land that stretches behind the shoreline to Craigielaw Point, the eastern extremity of Gosford Bay. At present Kilspindie has a membership of 450 men, 150 women and almost 50 juniors.
